qas.question: In what year did the AFL begin operating under the single-entity model?
Who owns the rights to the players under the single-entity model?
What model of ownership is commonly used in American professional sports?

context: The AFL currently runs as under the single-entity model, with <a1_0>the league<a1_0/> owning the rights to the teams, players, and coaches. The single-entity model was adopted in <a0_0>2010<a0_0/> when the league emerged from bankruptcy. Prior to that, the league followed the <a2_0>franchise model<a2_0/> more common in North American professional sports leagues; each team essentially operated as its own business and the league itself was a separate entity which in exchange for franchise fees paid by the team owners provided rules, officials, scheduling and the other elements of organizational structure. A pool of money is allotted to teams to aid in travel costs.
